articles.headline: Disruptions: Want Calls on Planes? You’ll Need to Speak Up
articles.snippet: It may be difficult for passengers on flights to get what many want — access to cellular data — without getting what many don’t want — the occasional Chatty Cathy in 21B.
articles.abstract: It may be difficult for passengers on flights to get what many want — access to cellular data — without getting what many don’t want — the occasional Chatty Cathy in 21B.
articles.lead_paragraph: You know there is trouble when Tony Robbins, the tirelessly upbeat Mr. Motivation, is sulking.

articles.headline: Thousands Demand Resignation of Ukraine Leader
articles.snippet: The largest showing of fury in 11 days over President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s refusal to sign political and trade accords with the European Union came as signs of fissure emerged within the government.
articles.abstract: The largest showing of fury in 11 days over President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s refusal to sign political and trade accords with the European Union came as signs of fissure emerged within the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Enraged by a violent crackdown by security forces, Ukrainians took to the streets with new, revolutionary urgency on Sunday, with hundreds of thousands of protesters demanding the resignation of President Viktor F. Yanukovich and a realignment of the country away from Russia toward Europe.

articles.headline: A Scorsese Film Gets In Under the Oscar Wire
articles.snippet: Martin Scorsese’s “The Wolf of Wall Street,” starring Leonardo DiCaprio, was completed last week and hurriedly scheduled for movie industry screenings.
articles.abstract: Martin Scorsese’s “The Wolf of Wall Street,” starring Leonardo DiCaprio, was completed last week and hurriedly scheduled for movie industry screenings.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last week, Martin Scorsese winged off to Marrakesh, Morocco, where he will spend nine days adjudicating Prince Moulay Rachid’s film festival.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Out of Print, Maybe, but Not Out of Mind
articles.snippet: Some features of physical books may be getting a second life online, but efforts to completely reimagine the core experience of the book have yet to catch on.
articles.abstract: Some features of physical books may be getting a second life online, but efforts to completely reimagine the core experience of the book have yet to catch on.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Books are dead. Long live the book.

articles.headline: Quiet Boss at Citigroup Setting Tone for Wall Street
articles.snippet: In an era of chastened Wall Street egos, Michael L. Corbat, the chief of Citigroup, has cultivated a workmanlike demeanor out of the spotlight.
articles.abstract: In an era of chastened Wall Street egos, Michael L. Corbat, the chief of Citigroup, has cultivated a workmanlike demeanor out of the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael L. Corbat, head of one of the biggest banks in the world, recently strolled through Marea, the Central Park South restaurant where Manhattan’s elite go to be seen.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Insurers Claim Health Website Is Still Flawed
articles.snippet: The site appears easier to use for most people, but problems in the systems that deliver consumer information to insurers still have not been fixed.
articles.abstract: The site appears easier to use for most people, but problems in the systems that deliver consumer information to insurers still have not been fixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks of frantic technical work appear to have made the government’s health care website easier for consumers to use. But that does not mean everyone who signs up for insurance can enroll in a health plan.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Gloomy Numbers for Holiday Shopping’s Big Weekend
articles.snippet: Over the course of the weekend, consumers spent about $1.7 billion less on holiday shopping than they did the year before, according to the National Retail Federation.
articles.abstract: Over the course of the weekend, consumers spent about $1.7 billion less on holiday shopping than they did the year before, according to the National Retail Federation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a cold, clear day in Leesburg, Va., and a security guard at an outlet mall there said the midmorning crowd was similar to that of a typical busy Saturday.

articles.headline: Long on Cutting Edge of Print, New York Magazine Cuts Back
articles.snippet: Next year, New York magazine will be printed every other week as it shifts resources to support its growing website.
articles.abstract: Next year, New York magazine will be printed every other week as it shifts resources to support its growing website.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1968, New York magazine has served as a prototype of literate, high-tempo publishing, using its weekly cadence and location in one of the world’s cultural capitals to usher in a new, more intimate and frank approach to what a publication could be.
